import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
selected_country1='New Zealand'
selected_country2=selected_country1

df1=pd.read_csv('../input/covid19-global-dataset/worldometer_coronavirus_daily_data.csv',header=0)
df1=df1[df1['country']==selected_country1]
df2=pd.read_csv('../input/covid-world-vaccination-progress/country_vaccinations.csv',header=0)
df2=df2[df2['country']==selected_country2]
df1.index=pd.to_datetime(df1['date'])
df2.index=pd.to_datetime(df2['date'])

fig,ax =plt.subplots(figsize=(10,5))
ax.plot(df1.index,df1['daily_new_cases'])
ax1=ax.twinx()
ax1.plot(df2.index,df2['daily_vaccinations'],'r')
plt.show()

#Improve visualization
from plotly.offline import iplot
import plotly.graph_objs as go

daily_new_cases = go.Scatter(x=df1.index,y=df1['daily_new_cases'],yaxis='y1',name='Daily confirmed cases')
daily_vaccinations = go.Scatter(x=df2.index,y=df2['daily_vaccinations'],yaxis='y2',name='Daily vaccinations')

layout_obj=go.Layout(title='Covid vs. Vaccines',xaxis= dict(title='Date'),yaxis=dict(title='Daily cases'),yaxis2=dict(title='Vaccinations',side='right',overlaying='y'))
fig=go.Figure(data=[daily_new_cases,daily_vaccinations],layout=layout_obj)
iplot(fig)
fig.write_html('outcome.html')

# Report
The country I choose in this assignment is New Zealand.

New Zealand is 

#40 for lowest total covid-19 cases

#45 for lowest daily covid-19 cases

#98 for both highest total people fully vaccinated per hundred and total vaccinations

#109 for highest daily vaccinations

We could see from the graph that New Zealand's highest daily cases is equal to 146 which is really low. This is because the government acted fast and closed the border strictly since the middle of March. Until now, New Zealand still closes its border to almost all non-citizens or residents. This is the main factor that make it be able to contain the virus. After the high numbers of daily cases in March, the number never exceed 40 people again. Most of the cases are also from managed isolation which makes it easy to control. Because the action is fast, the first spreader is always known and the quarantine is ordered for people involved in time. The covid-19 tests are also available and free.

For the vaccinations, the graph is like that because of the vaccination stages government has prepared. We can see that the number of vaccination rise at the start of May. This is because it is the time which the government started giving vaccines to people who are at risk of getting very sick from COVID-19 after already giving them to 'border and MIQ workers and the people they live with' and 'high-risk frontline workers and people living in high-risk places'.

One thing I observe from the ranking is that, using people vaccinated per hundred ranking, the ranking may not tell much informations. Most of the countries at the top are countries with small number of population. This makes it a lot easier for them to cover most of the populations. In my opinion, using this ranking is not fair for coutries with big popularity like New Zealand.
